chapters.title: Droughts are prolonged periods of abnormally low rainfall, causing insufficient water supply for human, animal, and plant needs. Unlike sudden natural disasters, droughts develop slowly but can persist for years or even decades. The Dust Bowl drought of the 1930s in North America caused severe economic hardship and led to the displacement of hundreds of thousands of people. Droughts trigger cascading effects including crop failures, water shortages, famine, and disease outbreaks. As global temperatures continue to rise, many regions face increased drought frequency and severity, particularly in areas already experiencing water stress.
